summary.body: Nick Cohen in the Standrd has had a cliched jibe at the Barbican tonight.  I think we should mail in to protest. To quote: "I went to the Museum of London .....  but spent as much time gawping at the Barbican complex ....   Nothing, not the doomed attempts of the residents to prettify the blocks with window boxes nore the late june sun, could make the brutalist towers look like anything other than an East German Housing project. Because it is in the centre of London and has a nice arts centre  attached, its flats still sell for 350k.  But it will take only one propoerty crash for the Barbican to meet its destiny and become what it was designed to be: a sink estate for the upper-middle class." Grrrrrrrrrrrrr............... Letters to   including daytime number, name and address !!!!!
summary.subject: Bad press for the Barbican

summary.body: take care crossing the streets in Feb....!  Shell backs Ferrari F1 with world's costliest ad (from Marketing mag 23 Jan) LONDON - Shell is to seal off the City of London and turn it into a mini Grand Prix-style racing circuit, as part of the filming of an ad highlighting its partnership with the Ferrari Formula One team. The TV execution, whose production cost 2m, making it the most expensive ad ever, will promote Shell's high-performance V-Power fuel. It is intended to support Shell's positioning as the most innovative fuel brand.  The ad will feature Ferrari F1 cars racing through some of the world's most famous cities, including New York and Sydney. The London leg of the ad, being created by JWT London, will be shot on 17 February, with the execution set to air globally in March.
summary.subject: Formula 1 in the City: 17 Feb

summary.body: I have been contacted by a Hong Kong based TV company interested in  taking in as a guest for just under a week a Chinese student, whose time with the family and as a tourist in London will be filmed for broadcast in Hong Kong. As they may need to wait some time to register here to place their message themselves, I offered to post it here for them and to put them in touch with anyone interested in participating. I have no information about this beyond the information they have given me, which I have copied below: "RE: Invitation for home visit to Barbican Estate for filming We are a TV production team of Radio Television Hong Kong (RTHK), please visit:   for more information about us. We produce educational TV programs in Hong Kong, China. We are currently working on a program called "Youth Travelogue" and would like ask for our favor to facilitate our filming. Program description: "Youth Travelogue" is a 22-minutes TV program about a new way of traveling. In this TV series, a Hong Kong youngster who grows up in Hong Kong's public housing will be arranged to visit other country's public housing.  By showing the presenters home staying with host families in different countries public housing, we hope to broaden audiences horizons and understanding of other countries unique social and cultural contexts. Know more about our presenter: Our presenter for this England episode is a 21-year-old young man, named Raisin, studying Linguistic and Finance in the University of Hong Kong. He is also a double-decker enthusiast. Our trip to England will also consist of the discovery of buses in England. What we need: We are looking for a host family who live in Council House in London. Given the unique architecture and historical background of Barbican Estate, we hope we can have the privilege to arrange a short home stay in the estate. The ideal host family would be open-minded and willing to share their daily life under our camera while they provide our presenter a 4~5 days' home stay with them. A small amount of remuneration will be given to the host family as a token of gratitude. The filming is scheduled to take place around Easter and we do wish this will be a wonderful opportunity for cultural exchange offered to both the host family and the presenter." I did point out to them that the Barbican is now almost entirely a private Estate, but it represents highly a successful example of post war public housing and they still want to come to the Barbican, specifically, although Golden Lane ought also to meet their criteria. Please PM me if you are interested, and I can put you in touch with the company concerned.
summary.subject: Barbican Filming Opportunity

summary.body: I was hearing this morning on the radio about various difficulties people have had getting Energy Performance Certificates done for the Home Information Packs that are now required when buying/selling a house. That made me wonder how the Barbican rated in energy efficiency terms. Would anyone who has seen a Barbican EPC be prepared to divulge what it said? I'm not a buyer/seller, but curious to see how it works nonetheless  and to see if the Barbie is energy efficient of course.  The government's website describes the EPC like this: 'Each rating is based on the performance of the building itself and its services (such as heating and lighting), rather than the domestic appliances within it. This is known as an asset rating. The certificate also lists the potential rating of the building if all the cost-effective measures were installed. The ratings will vary according to the age, location, size and condition of the building. The potential rating on the certificate will take these factors into account, and the suggested measures will be tailored so that they are realistic for the particular building.'
summary.subject: HIPS and Energy Performance Certificate
